transcripts.text: Thank you, Chairman Valpo, and members of the Health Policy Committee.  Yes, my name is Jennifer Behan.  I'm the Executive Director of Center for Inquiry of Michigan.  This is the local branch of an international nonprofit, Center for Inquiry.  We work to advance reason, science, and secular values in public affairs, and make sure that government policy is based on evidence, science, and compassion, rather than superstition, pseudoscience, or prejudice.  I do have a written copy that I have given you guys of my testimony, so I will paraphrase a few sections to keep it short for the chair's request.  I will say that I had an incorrect link on page two that I corrected before I emailed a PDF to the clerk, so that will have the corrected link in it for you guys to access.  I'm here to express opposition to House Bill 4710, because the state should only be licensing medical professions whose practices are supported by science and evidence.  It is essential for two reasons, to protect the public from dubious and potential practitioners, and also because the state licensure confers the authority of the state with the respectability that that provides the profession.  Contrary to what the practitioners and supporters have claimed, acupuncture is supported neither by science nor evidence.  Acupuncture has no basis in human physiology or science.  The meridians that they claim to use, where they supposedly put the needles, have no basis in anatomy.  And the life energy, the chi, whose flow that they claim to unblock or redirect has no basis in physics or chemistry and has never been detected or characterized.  It is claimed that acupuncture is effective for a wide variety of conditions with little or no relationship to the pathophysiology or root cause.  And from a scientific perspective, this is a very big flag because it cannot be shown to prove that it works for anything other than nonspecific effects.  Indeed, it has been often characterized as theatrical placebo because in the overall majority of the literature, it does not exceed placebo effect levels.  There is a link on the bottom of the first page that addresses that specific thing in detail.  And specifically, the FDA uses the standards when they approve new treatments that you have to show a significant effect over the placebo effect in order to show that it is actual and effective treatment.  So there are individual studies that do show that acupuncture can perform better than placebo for specific ailments.  But if you look at the examine, if you examine critically the total evidence, it's very clearly that it is indistinguishable from sham acupuncture or placebo effect.  So, one good example of this is a study that they did in 2009 in Germany.  They actually used toothpicks as a placebo control, and they simply twirled them on the people's skin in different places, and they did not even use them in the correct spots that were supposed to be for the acupuncture.  And the effects of the people that had that versus the true treatment were not distinguishable.  And there's a link to the article for that study there, as well as a comparative review of the research literature from the acupuncture evidence project.  And that is in the corrected link that I gave to the clerk.  The other concern that I have with this bill specifically is that this bill does not just seek to license acupuncturists.  They are actually going beyond that to expand the scope of practice to include a bunch of things that are grouped under the term traditional Chinese medicine, which is a very broad and vague term that has been used to include a lot of different things, including moxibustion, homeopathy, acupressure, cupping, dermal friction, and several other treatments.  Homeopathy in particular is very concerning because this is a scientifically discredited form of treatment.  In 2017, the Federal Trade Commission warned homeopathy marketers that if they are found to be misleading consumers, they will be found to be illegally misleading consumers unless they state clearly on the products that there is no scientific evidence that the product works.  So that should not be included in a bill on acupuncture anyway.  Additionally, acupuncture originated in Asia, though it's unclear when, and homeopathy originated in Germany in the late 1700s and has never been a part of traditional Chinese medicine at all.  So to include that is completely factually inaccurate.  The other treatments encompassed by the scope of the practice expansion granted to extra punctures by this bill are scarcely better in terms of their evidence base.  Traditional Chinese medicine, for instance, is based on pre-scientific beliefs about how the body works and is not validated by science.  And the other treatments in the list such as therapeutic exercise, dietary counseling, manual therapy are distinct therapies that should not be lumped under East Asian medical techniques.  These should be evaluated independently for licensure based on the scientific evidence available for those specific techniques.  I know the bill does state that the acupuncture is not to be doing any of the chiropractic or massage therapy under those other things.  but then if that's the case why are we even including that under the definition of east asian medical techniques?
thank you thank you very much for your testimony.  i'm going to allow one question and then we're going to try to get to all of the people that wish to speak.  so uh representative where?

Hi, thank you for coming today.  Can you let me know if your national organization and your organization, do they oppose the other 46 states that are licensed?  Yes, we do not think that acupuncture should be licensed in any state because there is not enough evidence to show that it actually is an effective treatment.  And at the national level and also in other state legislatures, we have gone and tried to advocate against bills, but we were unsuccessful.
Thank you.  Representative Pahutsky, if you have a short question, go ahead.

Thank you, Mr.  Chair.  I agree that we need to be cautious about legitimizing things that may not have scientific basis.  Would perhaps licensing this particular procedure, would that help make it safer or ensure that there were standards or is that counterintuitive?

Actually, as Representative Liberati pointed out, there really isn't much in the bill that actually addresses the safety standards.  And as the previous gentleman mentioned too, the new licensing is basically following the same model as the registration already.  So there really isn't any new information on how to regulate that and make sure that it's safe.
Thank you very much for your testimony.  Thank you very much for your time.
